customData.content: 69-year-old male diagnosed with primary peritoneal epithelioid mesothelioma of clear cell type. Swollen lymph nodes in the right inguinal region for 7 months. Dyssynergic defecation for 1 month. Presented to hospital in October 2018. History of asbestos exposure and a family history of cancer. CT scan revealed multiple cystic low-density shadows in the right renal parenchyma without obvious enhancement. Multiple nodules in the abdominal cavity. Left kidney shape was normal.

HPI.summary: Swollen lymph nodes in the right inguinal region

imaging.finding: multiple cystic low-density shadows without obvious enhancement
imaging.impression: multiple cystic low-density shadows in the right renal parenchyma without obvious enhancement
multiple nodules in the abdominal cavity

customData.content: Pelvic CT scan revealed a large tumor in the pelvic cavity with inhomogeneous enhancement. Intraoperative findings: Tumor nodules scattered on the surface of small intestinal mesentery (maximum diameter of 3.5 cm). Tumor nodules distributed on the surface of ligamentum teres and greater omentum (maximum diameter of 2 cm). Patchy tumor nodules scattered in bilateral subphrenic peritoneum (largest size of 6 x 6 x 0.8 cm). Tumor nodules present in the para-colonic sulcus bilaterally (3 cm on the left, 2 cm on the right). Peritoneum of the left lower abdominal wall adhered to sigmoid colon, harboring scattered small tumor nodules with invasion to rectum and mesorectum. Small intestine, mesentery, ileocecal and pelvic masses formed a dense adhesion at 400 cm from flexor ligament. Peritoneal Cancer Index (PCI) score was 24.

imaging.impression: Large tumor in the pelvic cavity with inhomogeneous enhancement

procedures.name: Exploratory laparotomy
procedures.outcome: Tumor nodules scattered on the surface of small intestinal mesentery (maximum diameter of 3.5 cm). Tumor nodules distributed on the surface of ligamentum teres and greater omentum (maximum diameter of 2 cm). Patchy tumor nodules scattered in bilateral subphrenic peritoneum (largest size of 6 x 6 x 0.8 cm). Tumor nodules present in the para-colonic sulcus bilaterally (3 cm on the left, 2 cm on the right). Peritoneum of the left lower abdominal wall adhered to sigmoid colon, harboring scattered small tumor nodules with invasion to rectum and mesorectum. Small intestine, mesentery, ileocecal and pelvic masses formed a dense adhesion at 400 cm from flexor ligament.

customData.content: Cytoreduction resulted in minimal residual disease. Gross examination revealed a huge (18 x 15 x 11 cm) tumor located in the pelvic cavity. The tumor section was grayish yellow, solid, and of medium texture. Two masses located in the omentum (2 x 2 x 0.3 cm, 1 x 0.8 x 0.5 cm). Section was grayish red and soft. Histopathological analysis: Most tumor cells arranged in sheet-like structures without papillary patterns. Some tumor cells arranged in tubular structures. Tumor cells had clear cytoplasm, were large and round to polygonal, displayed abundant clear cytoplasm with evident cytoplasmic membrane and eccentric small round nuclei. Mitotic figures were rare.

imaging.impression: Grayish yellow, solid, and of medium texture

imaging.finding: Two masses (2 x 2 x 0.3 cm, 1 x 0.8 x 0.5 cm)

diagnoses.label: Tumor cells arranged in sheet-like structures without papillary patterns
Tumor cells arranged in tubular structures
Tumor cells had clear cytoplasm, were large and round to polygonal, displayed abundant clear cytoplasm with evident cytoplasmic membrane and eccentric small round nuclei

customData.content: Immunohistochemical staining results: CK+, EMA+, CK7+, CAM5.2-, CK20-, CK8/18-, CK5/6-, Vimentin+, Calretinin Focal +, WT-1+, D2-40+, MC-, CD10-, RCC-, CD15-, PAX8-, CDX-2-, SATB2-, CDH17-, GATA3-, CEA-, B72.3-, Ber-EP4-, GPC3-, Hepatocyte-, HMB45-, Melan-A-, S100-, a-inhibin-, CD117-, Dog-1-, Erg-, FLI-1-, P63-, SMA-, Desmin Focally +, Ki67 Index 20%, P53+, DES Focally +, TTF-1-, INI-1+. Immunohistochemistry: Tumor cells exhibited diffuse strong staining for cytokeratins (CKs), Vimentin, D2–40, Wilms’ tumor 1 (WT-1) and INI-1. Tumor cells were focally positive for calretinin.

data.content: Patient progressed from initial presentation with swollen lymph nodes, dyssynergic defecation, and imaging findings of cystic shadows in the right renal parenchyma and abdominal nodules to a large pelvic tumor with inhomogeneous enhancement. Intraoperative findings revealed widespread tumor nodules throughout the peritoneum and adhesions involving the sigmoid colon and rectum. Peritoneal Cancer Index (PCI) score was 24.

Patient underwent cytoreduction resulting in minimal residual disease. Gross examination revealed a large tumor in the pelvic cavity and masses in the omentum. Histopathological analysis showed tumor cells arranged in sheet-like and tubular structures with clear cytoplasm and rare mitotic figures.

Immunohistochemical staining was performed on tumor cells, revealing diffuse strong staining for cytokeratins (CKs), Vimentin, D2–40, Wilms’ tumor 1 (WT-1) and INI-1. Tumor cells were focally positive for calretinin. Other markers were negative or focally positive as detailed in the immunohistochemical staining results.
